title: How EMI and Compound Interest Work
summary: Explore how banks calculate equated monthly instalments (EMI) using compound interest — a real-world application of exponential growth.
content:
Case Study: EMI and Compound Interest

Every home loan, car loan, and credit card in India uses compound interest. When you borrow ₹10 lakh at 8% per annum for 10 years, the bank calculates your EMI using the formula EMI = P·r(1+r)ⁿ/((1+r)ⁿ–1), where P is principal, r is monthly rate, and n is number of payments.

Key Mathematical Concepts

  • Compound Interest: A = P(1 + r/n)^(nt) — interest accrues on interest.
  • Geometric Series: The EMI formula emerges from summing a geometric series of present values.
  • Exponential Growth: Small interest rates over long periods produce surprisingly large totals.

Real-World Impact

Understanding this formula helps borrowers compare loan offers, evaluate prepayment benefits, and make informed financial decisions. India's financial literacy depends on citizens understanding compound interest.
